direction.raw_text: This once grand theater have been largely gutted - seats torn out, fixtures and fittings stripped, curtains ripped from the stage. But still, there's a sense of grandeur to this place. Looking out over the stage, a ROYAL BOX - once the most prestigious seat in the house - has been converted into an
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of sorts. Seats removed and replaced by an ORNATE MAHOGANY DESK facing inward, a CHANDELIER suspended above it. The whole set-up is gaudy and ostentatious - the work of someone who wants to project an aura of power and wealth, but has no taste whatsoever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is seated in a battered leather armchair behind the desk, deeply involved in an OLD PAPERBACK BOOK. The book's cover is faded and partially torn away, the title still just visible: 7 HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The man is OLDER than most we've seen. His skin weathered by the elements and by a long life's experience. One of the very few people we've seen in this world close to Eli's age - and unlike everyone else we've seen, he appears healthy and well- groomed. A rich mane of hair, full set of teeth. He wears a tattered SUIT AND TIE. None of it matches, everything scavenged from different outfits and eras. But he looks almost civilized. Respectable. His name is CARNEGIE. He looks up from his book at the sound of a POLITE COUGH O.S.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stands before him. Tall, powerfully built.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His accent is like caramel. A RICH, DEEP-SOUTH DRAWL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie lowers his book. Concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie stands. Thinking. This is bad news.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Survey team just finished up their inspection. It ain't good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How bad is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pressure is down again, and going by the new rod they sank levels're lower than they've ever been.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hard to say. Six months, maybe. A little longer if we're careful. But we're already-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Halve the rations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We just halved `em last-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So halve them again!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Carnegie stares Redridge down. Nobody but nobody questions his orders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie sighs, rubs his brow. He knows Redridge is right.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're going to have to say something. Folks were none too happy last time. Gonna be worse now, you can count on it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: EXT.
location: DAY A LARGE CROWD OF TOWNSFOLK

result.heading: AN ARMED CREW OF CARNEGIE'S GOONS

direction.raw_text: several hundred strong - has assembled outside the Palladium theater. AN ARMED CREW OF CARNEGIE'S GOONS keeps watch over the crowd. Carnegie stands on a BALCONY above the theater marquee. He treats the balcony like a pulpit, speaking through a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: connected to an old PA SYSTEM that carries his words to the far reaches of the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd listens intently, hanging on Carnegie's every word. He is an incredibly charismatic and persuasive speaker - his cultivated image and inspiring, confident delivery remind us of a TELEVISION EVANGELIST.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This sends a MURMUR OF DISCONTENT through the crowd. Many don't like where they suspect this may be going. Carnegie senses this and dials up his rhetoric - delivering it now with the fire-brand passion of an old-time baptist preacher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The crowd is divided. Many return the "Hallelujah" with varying levels of conviction. Others are not convinced. But Carnegie continues unabated, selling it harder than ever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie is such an impassioned and inspiring speaker it's almost impossible not to get caught up and swept away by his words. His apparently unshakable belief is infectious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This sends a much broader ripple of discontent through the crowd - this news has not been received well at all. Some still "keep the faith" but many more are perturbed by this. Carnegie motions for the crowd to settle down.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I want you all to remember how far we've come together. And how far we still can go, if only we believe. When I brought us here to this oasis - this promised land - we knew there would be hardships. Knew there would be sacrifices. But we also knew that we were creating for ourselves a world where we could be safe from the horrors of the forsaken lands beyond our borders.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I want you all to remember above all that it is not the water with which we have been blessed that is the true lifeblood of this town... but faith.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is our faith that sustains us, brothers and sisters! Hallelujah!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And mark me, the ultimate validation of that faith is coming! The sacred Word of Our Lord that formed the world before and will reform it once again is coming to this town to bring it succor, bring it nourishment, bring it new life! For the Almighty Himself has spoken unto me and promised it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the meantime, He has asked us all to be patient. To walk the hard road of the faithful just a little longer. And to do that, we must give just a little more. (BEAT) Water rations will be halved until further notice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand your frustration. The road to salvation is a difficult one - but what lies at the end of that road is a greater glory, beyond anything you can imagine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: steps forward, pushing through the crowd and jabbing his finger angrily up at Carnegie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie's goons quickly move in and efficiently SILENCE THE MAN, removing him from the crowd. Dissent is not tolerated here. Carnegie goes on speaking as if nothing had happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie steps back inside, leaving the crowd to talk among themselves, clearly mixed about what they have heard. As the assembled townsfolk disperse, FOUR MOTORCYCLES roar into town and pull up outside the Palladium. As the riders dismount, one detaches a CLOTH SATCHEL from his bike's cargo rack. The four riders head inside. They each have long, straggly hair and brutish expressions. We recognize them now as the BIKER BANDITS who killed the couple on the road under the freeway overpass.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We've heard this all before! When are you going to-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know each and every one of you will understand the necessity of this action. It was faith that built this town - and faith that will sustain it even through the dark times that may lie ahead. But it is always darkest before dawn - and the new dawn is coming. (BEAT) May God go with you all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carnegie emerges into the second-floor hallway from the balcony, mopping his brow. Exhausted and stressed from his grand theatrical display, and from its mixed reception. Redridge climbs the stairs to meet him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie looks at his cracked old wristwatch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That gets Carnegie's attention.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: One of the road crews just rolled into town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course they did, the bar's open. Outlanders, always looking for answers at the bottom of a bottle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not these guys. (BEAT) These guys say they got something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get them up here now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: What was once a grand, gilded entrance foyer has, like the rest of the theater, been largely gutted. But it's still impressive - a spacious bar area with a grand staircase leading up to a second floor, entrance to balcony seats, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: still hang from the walls. The place has been shabbily converted into a kind of SALOON. Old ripped-out theater seats arranged around tables. A FIREPLACE sputters dimly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walks across the straw-laden floor. A dozen or so CUSTOMERS in the place, a mixed, rough-looking bunch. Redridge emerges from an upstairs room and nods to a group of his MEN who are holding the bikers at the foot of the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie checks his reflection in a CRACKED HAND MIRROR, licks his palm and slicks his hair back. He adjusts his tie as Redridge's men usher the bikers into his "office". Carnegie wheels around and flashes a smile at them. Just as when he gave his balcony address, Carnegie is in performance mode - charismatic and slick like a campaigning politician.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bikers exchange looks. They understood maybe half the words in that sentence. The lead biker - named HOG - speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hog tips the satchel's contents out onto Carnegie's desk.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen! It's truly a delight to see you again! I understand your latest excursion into the outland has been a profitable one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We did good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, let's see, shall we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . About a dozen different volumes of all shapes and sizes. Carnegie rifles excitedly through the collection. We see various titles as he sorts through them. Treasure Island. The Da Vinci Code. A volume of encyclopedia. The Diary of Anne Frank. Tuesdays with Morrie. In amongst the books are a few MAGAZINES. An old issue of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: magazine. A torn copy of SPORTS ILLUSTRATED...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ...And a NEWSWEEK. The cover graphic illustrates OPPOSING NUCLEAR ARSENALS over a world globe. On one side the STARS AND STRIPES, on the other flags indicating a SINO-ISLAMIC ALLIANCE. The headline reads: "IS THERE NO TURNING BACK?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Carnegie rejects each book with growing disappointment and frustration, it's clear he's looking for a specific volume.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bikers exchange more looks. An unspoken conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie's guards bristle, ready for a confrontation. Carnegie just smiles, always ready to smooth things over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As always, his carefully stage-managed rhetoric is delivered with the utmost conviction, every word dripping with passion and persuasion. He's a master salesman, a true huckster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He steps forward and looks Hog right in the eye. His gaze like a laser beam, utterly disarming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's impossible not to be swayed by this guy. He's just so full of fiery passion and infectious belief, you almost want to reach into your pocket and hand over your wallet. Hog snatches up his empty satchel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and marches to the door, the other bikers following. The guards escort them out, only Redridge remains. Carnegie slumps back into his chair, frustrated, pissed off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie and Redridge lock eyes. BEAT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie ignores him. Stands, walks toward the door. Redridge sighs, gestures toward the books piled on Carnegie's desk.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No. No. No. No. No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These ain't worth nothin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you bring me the book I asked you for, it'll be worth something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We been doin' this a long time now. Had to make a whole lotta corpses to bring you all these books. You want us to keep at it, reckon it's worth more than a few free glasses of that swill you call liquor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen, gentlemen. I urge you once again to take the long view here. When we find this book - and believe me, we will find it - we are going to build a new world. A world far greater, far more righteous than this one. And you and I are going to be perched right on top of it, looking down upon it, masters of all creation!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you know, I think you're absolutely right. (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) That is worth more than a few glasses of liquor. A whole lot more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The book I want is out there somewhere, just waiting to be found. Once there were millions of copies - you only need to find one! Find it and bring it here. And I promise you, you will be rewarded beyond anything you can imagine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This better not be bullshit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Might help if they knew just what they were looking for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not one of them can read. How would they even know when they found it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So how's about you just tell me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two years now you been sending these crews into the outland. Burning up gas we can barely spare. For a goddamn book? What the hell kinda book can be worth all this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about these?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put them with the others.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Redridge stands by the marble fireplace, tossing the books into the fire. The flames flicker and leap around the books as their pages blacken and are consumed by the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli watches as the engineer charges the battery with the gas generator, which chugs noisily. He licks his lips, dry as sand. Unscrews his canteen to take a drink, but it's down to its last few drips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli thinks a while longer. Then stands and stuffs his shotgun inside his pack, shoulders his gear and makes for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli stops in the doorway and turns back to the engineer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And with that he turns and leaves. The engineer gulps. Not a hint in Eli's voice that he didn't mean every word.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's this place across the street? They got any water?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got our own underground spring here. Only fresh water in a hundred miles - if's you can pay for it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If that battery ain't here when I get back, I will use this gun on your kneecaps and I will put this building to the torch and I will watch it burn to the ground with you alive inside it. So help me God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: This old second-floor DRESSING ROOM has been converted into a bedroom, simply furnished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stands in front of an old DRESSING ROOM MIRROR, the bulbs around the frame burned-out and broken. She washes her face in murky water in an old PORCELAIN BOWL on the dresser. Her name is CLAUDIA. Early 30s, pretty. She gazes into the mirror as she dries her hands, but it's so cracked and warped it's near impossible to see a reflection. The door opens and Carnegie enters. He still looks steamed. Claudia doesn't turn to look at him, keeps facing the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie says nothing. Just paces angrily up and down. Finally Claudia turns to face him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie trails off, the thought too awful to contemplate. Claudia adopts a sympathetic expression, supportive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This seems to anger Carnegie. He wheels on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She detects the aggressive tone in his voice and goes quiet, head bowed. Carnegie moves toward her angrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's in her face now. Claudia avoids eye contact, submissive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's shouting now, and she's trembling, afraid to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie realizes he's frightened her. He softens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lifts her chin up, wipes away a tear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts his hands on her lustfully. It's clear she's not in the mood, but she halfheartedly responds anyway. More out of a sense of wifely duty than reciprocated passion. As they kiss, Carnegie pushes her excitedly against the wall and feverishly begins unbuckling his pants.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is that you, honey?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: More books came in from the road today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh? It's been a while.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And it'll be a while longer. Just another pile of useless junk. If we don't find the right one soon - if I can't give these people what they want to hear...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll find what you're looking for. It's out there somewhere. You just have to have faith.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Faith? Is that what you think we're missing around here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My old man used to have faith. He had it in spades. My mother, too. (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) You know where it got them? You know where it got me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Faith is for the weak. It's for them out there, the sheep. This world is what you can see and touch and taste. It's what you make it. All these years with me, you still don't have any grasp of that? What's wrong with you, woman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to scare you. Hey. You okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just get me all riled up with that kind of talk. It's not what I need from you right now. (SMILES) You know what I need right now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The original customers have now been joined by the four bikers, who sit at their own table drinking a clear and pungent moonshine-type liquor from a shared jar. Eli enters. All eyes are on him immediately, regarding him with guarded interest as he pulls up a stool at the bar. The BARTENDER approaches, looks him up and down. Suspicious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Eli raises his hand as before. Holds it outstretched, steady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli places the canteen on the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli takes off his scarf and puts it on the bar. The bartender takes it and looks it over. Not particularly impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bartender spies Eli's silver Saint Christopher pendant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli stuffs the pendant inside his shirt. No way that's for sale. Instead, he reaches into his coat and produces the fur pelts he skinned from the dead cat, lays them out on the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bartender takes a pelt and examines it. The mangy cat leaps up onto the bar and approaches. Sniffs at the pelts with suspicion and HISSES at Eli. Eli shoos the cat off the bar with a wave of his hand. At the biker's table Hog watches this, not happy about this. Satisfied with the pelts, the bartender gathers them up along with the scarf, then turns away toward the back room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Outlander? Let me see-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'll it be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the good stuff. Gotta eat into my own ration to sell it - so I don't sell it cheap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That'll get you maybe half-way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the best I got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Solara!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: emerges from the back. No older than 16 or 17. Dressed in unflattering work clothes, face grimy, blonde hair tied back in a ponytail. But even through all this, it's clear she is a strikingly beautiful young woman. The bartender takes Eli's canteen and hands it to Solara along with a RATION CARD he keeps around his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Solara takes the canteen, pausing for a moment to look Eli up and down. Unsure quite what to make of him, but intrigued. There's something about him she can't put her finger on... He doesn't look back at her. She turns and exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Take this out back and get it filled.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: ENCLOSURE OF CHAIN-LINK FENCE TOPPED WITH RAZOR WIRE

direction.raw_text: Solara exits via the Palladium's STAGE DOOR and walks across the busy street to where TWO OF CARNEGIE'S ARMED MEN stand guard around an ENCLOSURE OF CHAIN-LINK FENCE TOPPED WITH RAZOR WIRE. TOWNSFOLK wait in line with bowls and buckets. One of the guards recognizes Solara and lets her cut to the front of the line. He punches two holes in her ration card and lets her inside the chain-link enclosure. Inside is an OLD RUSTED SPIGOT attached to a pipe emerging from the earth. Solara cranks hard on the handle - it takes a few pulls before the water comes, and then only at a weak trickle; it will take a while to fill the canteen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Eli sits at the bar, a SHADOW comes into view and looms large over him. Hog is standing behind him, glaring, cutting a menacing figure in his armored cycle leathers. Solara senses trouble brewing and moves off, taking Eli's canteen away into the back room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli doesn't turn. Just looks straight ahead. Impossible to read him behind those mirrored goggles. Utterly inscrutable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bartender looks at Hog nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hog grabs him by the arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Blink. Suddenly Hog's head is pinned to the bar by nothing more than Eli's thumb. Pressed deep into a nerve cluster in his neck. Eli leans in close as Hog whimpers, paralyzed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other bikers stand and approach, the OTHER CUSTOMERS following suit. Eli senses the trouble gathering behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all Hog can do to just barely nod his head. Eli releases his thumb. Hog staggers backward, gasping for breath. Eli stands and makes toward the door, but the bikers and other patrons have moved to block his exit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli sighs, looks down at the floor. He's been pushed one time too many today. For the first time, we see anger in his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The patrons look at Eli strangely. Who is this guy? Eli reaches back and draws the samurai sword. Carves a line in the dirt at his feet with the tip of the blade.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That was my cat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine specimen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw you push him off the bar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't push him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You raised your hand at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry. It won't happen again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, how about another drink, Hog?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That cat's been comin' in here for nigh on two years. It got more right to be here than you. Who the fuck do you think you are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want any trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's too bad, `cause-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know you. Murderer of innocent travelers on the road. You're going to spend eternity drowning in a lake of fire for the things that you've done. Did you know that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You go on back to your table and I'll be on my way. All right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You push Hog, you push all of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cursed be the ground because of you. By toil shall you eat of it. Thorns and thistles shall it sprout for you. From the ground were you taken. For dust you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And to dust you shall return.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carnegie has Claudia pinned against the wall, his pants bunched around his ankles, ass bared as he pounds away at her. Not making love. This is mechanical, loveless sex. Claudia stares vacantly over his shoulder into space as Carnegie thrusts into her again and again. Deeply uninterested, just waiting for it to be over. Suddenly, we hear a CRASH O.S. Carnegie stops and listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claudia sees an opening to get out of this.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you hear that? What was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you should go check.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Carnegie keeps listening. Then comes another CRASH.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls up his pants, grabbing a RIFLE propped by the door as he rushes out. Claudia just stands there for a moment, then reaches down and pulls up her panties. She moves from the wall and makes her way across the room, feeling her way with her hands, gazing off into nothingness. Only now do we finally realize that she is BLIND.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What in the hell is going on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carnegie emerges from the bedroom onto the balcony. Looks down over the railing - and is stunned by what he sees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in the bar below. Eli cutting a one-man swath of mayhem through the dozen brawlers. Most already lie dead. TWO MORE MEN ATTACK Eli and are effortlessly felled by his sword. Carnegie rushes hurriedly along the landing, banging loudly on the doors of the upstairs rooms.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get your asses out here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Surrounded by the dead, only one man left standing. Hog. He backs away as Eli circles him like a predator. Sword held ready, the blade glistening with dark red blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: re-emerges from the back room with Eli's refilled canteen. She stops and emits a horrified GASP when she sees the bloody carnage laid out in the bar before her. She watches, mortified, as Eli moves toward the helpless, terrified Hog, going in for the kill. Raising his sword... Suddenly, Solara steps forward and CRIES OUT:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli FREEZES. Sword hanging in the air, poised to strike. He turns his head to where Solara stands behind the bar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stop!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Eli considers. He looks back at Hog, still completely at his mercy... and then LOWERS THE SWORD.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hog stumbles backward through the door, into the sunlight. Eli moves toward Solara, who stands petrified behind the bar. Reaches out and gently pries the canteen from her loose grip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . In the exitway, Hog turns back inside, grabbing up a BROKEN BOTTLE from the bloody floor as he goes. Hog rushes Eli from behind. Solara sees him coming and goes to SCREAM - but before any sound can come, Eli flips his sword backward and Hog runs right onto it, SKEWERING HIMSELF.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It ain't for me to judge you. Your time for that's gonna come. Believe me. Now go on. Get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Hog just stands there for a moment, eyes wide, frozen in shock. His fingers go limp, dropping the bottle. He slides off the sword and collapses to the floor, dead. Eli wipes the sword clean and sheathes it. Looks around at the bloodied, fallen bodies. Then back at Solara.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he turns and heads toward the door:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Accompanied by the sound of MULTIPLE GUNS COCKING. Carnegie is on the landing, training his rifle down at Eli. Alongside him, FIVE GUNMEN do the same. They've got him cold.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry for all the mess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hold it right there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carnegie sits at his desk, the huge auditorium and stage area visible behind him. Eli stands before him. Around him are the other gunmen, who keep their weapons trained on him. Standing at Carnegie's side are REDRIDGE and CLAUDIA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie's gunmen look him over, inspecting him warily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Carnegie's confident gaze remains fixed on Eli throughout.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli can't help but react at the mention of that word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli doesn't respond. Just stands there in Carnegie's gaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barely noticeable, Carnegie gestures to one of the gunmen, who nods in acknowledgement and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mention of that word rankles Carnegie. He walks around the desk toward Eli, waves an admonishing finger at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie can't help himself - once again he is in his natural element, spinning the argument his way, pitching. Selling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An impressive, impassioned performance. He sounds just like an old-school TV evangelist. But Eli is unmoved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli doesn't respond. Just stands there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's good. Good man. We educated folk, we need to stick together, if we're ever going to rebuild this world. People like you and me, we're the future.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want with me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Straight to the point. I like that. Fact is, you could be in a lot of trouble. This is a peaceful town. You walk in here, armed, and the next thing a dozen of my good citizens are dead. I've hanged men for less. I could hang you. (BEAT) Or, you could come work for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never once saw anyone handle themselves the way you did down there in that bar. I don't know where you learned it, but I sure as hell could use it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not interested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People who work for me can live better than any walker ever dreamed. Real beds, clean water, hot food. Women, even. You could do a lot worse, my friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not your friend. And I'm not staying. I got someplace I need to be. Out west.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: West? There is nothing west. It's all gone, a long time ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been told different.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli doesn't reply. Carnegie smiles, dials up the charm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gunmen bristle, exchange nervous looks. Carnegie appears unfazed. He smiles. BEAT. He looks to the gunman at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gunman opens the door. Eli turns and exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So, who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody. A walker in the outland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've met walkers before. Not a particularly civilized bunch. Some have even taken to eating their own kind, did you know that? You wouldn't be one of those savages now, would you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He ain't got the shakes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. This is a civilized town. Under God. Do you know what that means?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It means we have laws here. Laws set down long before any of us ever walked this earth. And one of them is, you don't eat the flesh of your brother. Else you're no better than an animal. And not welcome here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what's your business here, friend? Walkers don't usually come into town less they want something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had a battery needed charging and a canteen needed filling. I didn't come here looking for trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you sure as hell found it. Do you know who I am?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name's Carnegie. I own this bar. I own the whole town. You've never heard of me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's you out there on the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Remarkable likeness, isn't it? You'd never guess half the men who built it were blind. A small tribute from a grateful people. I was deeply touched.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You had slaves build you a monument to yourself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't call them slaves. That's an old word. I'm not a slaver. I'm trying to help these people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the outland the sightless are preyed upon like sick animals. Here at least they're protected. They do the essential work others don't want. And in return they eat, they drink, they survive. Last year, a couple of them even got married - performed the ceremony myself. (BEAT) You see, I'm not exploiting these people - I'm saving them! Any one of them is free to leave whenever they wish. But here they stay. And they thank me every single day for their salvation!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's none of my business what you do here. Like you said, it's your town. I just want to be on my way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's your name, walker?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, I guess we just call you Walker. Don't see too many folks your age these days. You lived in the world before? You can read?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I read every day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, look. I'm going to make you an offer of goodwill. Stay the night, think it over. Try a little local hospitality. We'll talk again in the morning. If you're still not interested, you're free to go. No hard feelings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you for your offer. But I'd prefer to just leave right now. So you can either let me out of here, or I can kill my way out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let him go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The engineer stands behind the counter, looking worried. His heart sinks when he sees Eli enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli leans in a little closer. He smells a rat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli looks at the engineer. Hard to be certain, but he's pretty sure he's lying. Somebody got to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, shit...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's my battery?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's, uh... it's gonna take a little longer than I thought.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much longer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's gotta charge overnight. You, uh, you can always stay here in town, pick it up in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You remember what I said would happen if I came back here and you didn't have my battery?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's right here! It's just gonna take a while longer. I swear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is heard from down the hall. Suddenly one of Carnegie's henchmen comes flying into view as he is THROWN HARD INTO A WALL and slumps to the floor, unconscious. Eli storms into the box, pissed. MORE GUARDS rush in behind him. Carnegie, seated behind his desk, waves the guards off as he stands to greet Eli, smiling ingratiatingly as ever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie is a practiced liar. Much more difficult to read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Redridge - one of the two men who chased Eli into the room - steps forward. He regards Eli with a distrustful eye.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I knew you'd reconsider.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? How'd you know that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: None of the walkers I've seen come here from the outland were ever what you'd call smart. I mean all those years out there alone on the road, some with their brains half- fried from eating each other - it's understandable why you people aren't the brightest bulbs in the box. But I never met one so dumb that he'd turn down a meal and a bed if it was offered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you didn't send someone across the street to the engineer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Engineer? I don't know what you're talking about. If there's something wrong, maybe I can help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is Redridge. He's kind of my right-hand man around here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'll show you to your room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Redridge opens the door and ushers Eli inside. It's another of the dressing rooms converted into a bedroom, less well-appointed than Carnegie's own. A threadbare rug. Bed with relatively clean sheets. A sink for washing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Redridge smirks and closes the door, leaving Eli alone. Eli paces across the room. Finally sits down on the creaky old bed. Trying to figure out how he managed to get stuck here. He unshoulders his pack, sets it down. Lies down on the bed. It's been a while since he felt a real bed on his back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Enjoy your stay. There'll be someone outside your room all night. If you need anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: at the door. Eli gets quickly to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens and CLAUDIA enters. Carrying a metal tub of water in both hands and, atop that, a dinner tray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli just stands there. Totally unfamiliar with this kind of situation, it's been too long. She smiles, embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes the stuff from her, sets it on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We get the impression that Claudia is as unfamiliar with this kind of polite interaction as Eli. But she likes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She strikes a match and lights the oil lamp on the table. The room is lit by its flickering glow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she turns for the door:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claudia smiles. Neither has she.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have this for you. Water for washing and some food.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... are you going to take it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're very welcome.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It'll be dark soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I get you anything else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well. Have a good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're Carnegie's woman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you ask?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just making conversation is all. Haven't had one of those in a while. Not a real one, leastways.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He found me in the outland. I was sixteen, my family had been... well, they were gone. There was just me and my baby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You had a baby?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd met some men on the road. Bad men. They...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . She trails off, struggling with this unhappy memory. Eli gets it, raises a hand reassuringly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a bittersweet quality to Claudia's words. As though there is more to the story than she is telling. Eli pulls out a chair at the table, offers it to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles and sits. Eli sits across from her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again, bittersweet. The sense that Claudia feels trapped. Thinking about it begins to upset her. She gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Eli stands, escorts her to the door and opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli closes the door, then sits back at the table.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was on the road for a year after that. I couldn't feed myself, let alone my little girl. And then Bill found us and he promised he'd take care of us. He told me he was going to make a place where we could be safe. And he did. He did all that. He built this whole town. He kept us safe. And he raised that child like she was his own. He's been so good to both of us. He saved us, really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to eat some?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When did you go blind? In the war? You get caught in a flash?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I was born this way. I think I'm lucky like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lucky?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not like I ever knew what I'm missing. I was already used to being like this by the time... by the time it all happened. So I got around pretty good even when I was on my own. And now it's easy. I know every creaky old floorboard in here, and it's not like I ever go any place else. Bill would never allow it. He worries about me so much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should go. He'll be wondering where I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. I enjoyed our conversation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So did I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carnegie washes, looking at himself in the old dressing-room mirror. He sees Claudia enter the room in its dim reflection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A subtly accusing tone. It makes Claudia nervous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claudia moves to the bedside, begins to undress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claudia reacts suddenly to this. Shocked and angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie sighs, tiring of this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claudia looks at Carnegie in disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now it's Carnegie's turn to get angry. He rounds on her menacingly. She backs off as he approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has her against the wall, his face just inches from hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie calms himself, backs off. Claudia goes to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie surges forward and pins Claudia to the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He releases his grip on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He speaks more softly now. As he strokes his hand tenderly through Claudia's hair, a tear runs down her cheek.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You took your time in there. How long does it take to deliver a plate of food and some water?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wanted to talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh? What about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing really. He asked me what it was like to be blind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He tell you anything about him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I don't think he likes to talk about himself much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I got that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think he's going to change his mind by morning. I don't think he's going to stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What makes you say that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just strikes me as the kind of man who's of a mind, is all. Doesn't seem like the type to go changing it once it's set.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, we'll just see about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You saw him. He's not like the others. You won't be able to smooth- talk him and wrap him around your finger like you usually do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who said anything about me? (BEAT) I'm sending Solara.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're doing what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know how often these walkers get laid? Never. Least not by anything living or willing. Girl like her can be very persuasive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't send her in there with him. He's dangerous, he's a killer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You went in there readily enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's different. Solara's just a child, she can't-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's a grown woman now, Claudia. Sooner or later you're going to have to accept that. She has to earn her keep around here, same as the rest of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By working as a whore? That's all you think she's fit for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've each been given a talent to help us make our way in this world. Some people's gift is more evident than others. Solara's sure as hell is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of a man are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm the kind of man who'd pull a helpless blind girl off the road, a girl who'd been beaten and raped, and give her a place where she can live without fear! Without me you'd be just another no-eye, lying dead in the outland, picked clean by the buzzards, or shoveling dirt down there with the others. That's the kind of man I am!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't live without fear. I haven't for a long time now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going to let you do this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not going to let me? (BEAT) Nobody tells me what I can and can't do in my own town. Nobody. I built this world, and I am God here! So don't go thinking about screwing with my plans. You know how this works. Solara goes against me, you get hurt. You go against me, she gets hurt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So let's not see anybody get hurt. Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dark outside, but the room is brightly lit by the glow of the oil lamp. Eli sits up on his bed, quietly reading the old leather-bound book from his backpack. Another KNOCK at the door. Eli jumps up and hurriedly hides the book inside his shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens to reveal Solara. Looking very different than she did before. Cleaned up and wearing a flowery summer dress, blonde hair let down over her shoulders. Stunning. Unlike everyone else we have met, she seems - physically, at least - totally unscarred by the horrors of the times. Far too beautiful a thing to belong in a world like this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She glides into the room, closing the door. She's good. Very seductive. Eli is totally disarmed in her presence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't wait for an answer. Moves to the table and turns down the oil lamp. A darker, more seductive lighting scheme.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits on the bed, kicks her legs playfully. Her light cotton dress revealing in all the right places. The silhouette of her body bathed in the seductive glow of the oil lamp. No red-blooded man on earth could resist her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leans over on the bed, resting on her elbow. Her hair cascades down. God damn, she looks good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slides off the bed, approaches him. Begins to work the buttons of his shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves her hand away. Gently pushes her back a step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is stunned. No man has ever turned her down before. And then she seems a little insulted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Eli opens the door for her.

dialogue.raw_text: Fine! I'll do just that! I had a life there! A family! I didn't ask you to save me! I didn't ask you for anything!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine.

direction.raw_text: A small, penned-in area to the rear of the Palladium containing an eclectic bunch of farmyard animals. Goats, sheep, geese, pigs. Mostly mangy, sad-looking specimens. Carnegie stands in the yard, tossing handfuls of animal feed from a nearby sack onto the ground. He watches with satisfaction as the animals gather at his feet to feed. Claudia emerges from the theater with an ice-pack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie applies it to his jaw, red and swollen from Eli's pistol-whip. Redridge appears nearby, his arm in a sling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie doesn't appear to be listening. He is lost in a world of his own as he tends to the farm animals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carnegie finally looks up from his animals, at Redridge.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, darling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He killed four of my men and walked out of town without a scratch. They shot off a hundred rounds at him and he didn't get hit once. I never even heard of anything like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, I always thought of myself as a shepherd. Bringing together the wayward and the lost. Tending to my flock. But all the things I want to do, I can't do them on my own. The one thing I've needed is the one thing that's always been missing. Then one day it walks right into town - so close I can almost touch it - and then walks right on out again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to put a crew together and go out after him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's not going to work for you. I think he's made that plain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not interested in him any more. I only want the book he's carrying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I'm gonna risk my ass hunting down this maniac in the outland, I need to know it's gonna be worth it. I need to know what's so special about this goddamn book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Carnegie considers this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns back to his animals, summoning up old memories.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He snaps out of his reverie and looks at Redridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As usual, Carnegie's slick rhetoric has worked - Redridge has totally bought into it. Claudia, however, looks appalled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches out and takes Claudia by the hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles halfheartedly, but it's clear she is mortified. Carnegie turns back to Redridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Redridge nods and goes to leave.

dialogue.raw_text: You have no idea. You're too young, you don't remember the world before. But I do. I remember.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I was a kid my parents used to read that book every goddamn day. My mother, she'd read it along with this smooth-talking preacher on the
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: screen. They used to be able to beam these guys right into your house, into every house in the world, through the air. Like magic. (BEAT) She worked two jobs and she sent every spare penny she had to that fucking guy on the TV. My old man, he'd read that book, then he'd get liquored up and kick my ass, tell me all about the power and the glory and how I was going to burn forever in hell for the sins I was born with. He made sure he beat it into me good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you see? It's not just any book. (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) It has the power to motivate people. It can give them hope, it can terrify them. It can shape them. Control them. (BEAT) Do you remember how I built this town? It wasn't done with force, and it wasn't done just with water. It was done with the power of words. I created this place out of nothing, because people believed in a promise that I sold to them. Those guys on the TV, they were richer than you could ever dream, and it was all built the same way. With words. With promises. And with that book. (BEAT) That book is a weapon. Aimed right at the hearts and minds of the weak and the desperate. Just imagine what I could do with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boss... we're running out of water and the people are running out of patience. You're trying to tell me that a book is going to keep them in line?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, it'll do much more than that. The water in this town may run dry, but faith - that springs eternal! And that faith will help turn this town into a city. And this city into a nation. It will help me build a new world. In my image. People will come from far and wide to hear what's inside of it. They'll follow me anywhere just to get a taste of it. And they'll do whatever I tell them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what if this book don't work? What if it don't say what you want it to say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, it'll say what I want, I can promise you that. Because I'm going to rewrite it. I'll keep the parts that work for me and make the rest whatever I need it to be. (BEAT) A new bible, for a new world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you think, darling? A whole new world, to do with as we will. Won't that be grand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Find that book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He has half a day on us already.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So use the motor pool.

dialogue.raw_text: There ain't much gas in reserve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whatever there is, use it.

dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . In all this excitement about the book, she had been completely forgotten about.

direction.raw_text: . Redridge turns and leaves. Claudia scowls at Carnegie, but he doesn't even notice, just goes back to feeding his animals.

dialogue.raw_text: She's still out there. With him.

dialogue.raw_text: Right. Right. Of course. Bring her back, too, if you can. But-

direction.raw_text: Solara wanders the road. She's tired. The sun beats down mercilessly. Nothing but desolation and wasteland all around. She comes to a FORK IN THE ROAD. Stops at the junction, unsure. Was this here before? She doesn't remember. There are no signs. Both paths look the same. Which one is which? She turns and looks back, looks around. She's lost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She alternates her finger between the two paths. Eeny-meeny- miney-moe. Picks a path and follows it, headed down the road.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Shit. Shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Eli walks on. Slow and steady. His gaze, as ever, fixed firmly on the horizon. Takes a swig from his canteen. Suddenly, he STOPS and stands stock still in the center of the road. Impossible to know what he's thinking. He stands there for a long time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Solara comes upon an abandoned CHEVRON STATION. She doesn't remember passing this. Looks back up and down the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a RUSTED CAR parked at one of the pumps. Like every other car we've seen, stripped of its tires and engine. She walks around to the driver's side. A PETRIFIED FEMALE BODY lies on the ground, half-in, half-out of the car. Solara claps her hand to her mouth and recoils, horrified. In the dead woman's hand is a dusty bottle of MINERAL WATER. Solara hesitates. Not wanting to get closer. But so thirsty. She braces herself, grimacing, and tries to take the bottle, but the dead woman's hand is closed tight around it. She pulls harder and wrenches it free. In the process she falls on her butt and flips the corpse over onto its back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . In the other woman's arm, she has a SKELETAL BABY cradled to her bosom. It seems to be staring right at Solara. Solara SCREAMS and frantically shuffles backward away from it. Gets to her feet and runs across the forecourt. She stops by the station shop and rests against the wall, hyperventilating, heart pounding. Trying to get it together. She inspects the water in the bottle. It looks clean. Unscrews the cap with shaking hands and takes a sip. She SPITS IT BACK OUT, coughing. It's rank. Undrinkable.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where the hell am I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Solara enters. Gloomy inside. Comprehensively looted. Empty shelves coated in thick sheets of dust. She moves further in, searching for something, anything. But the place has been gutted. There's nothing. She checks the wall of dead refrigerators. Shattered glass, all empty. She's never known desolation and emptiness like this. It's beginning to scare her. She wheels around in a panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Distant, calling from outside. Solara hears it and freezes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hello? Can anyone help me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She runs out across the forecourt, onto the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Solara starts walking toward her. The woman has her back to Solara. She's on her knees, muttering to herself. Gathering objects up from the road. As Solara moves closer, we see that the woman is struggling with an UPTURNED SHOPPING CART. Stuck in a roadside ditch, its contents spilled out next to a few BRACKEN BUSHES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . We see her face now. It's the SAME YOUNG WOMAN from before. The same shopping cart. The same trap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The woman looks around, sees Solara standing nearby. She's shocked to see that it's a girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The woman seems anxious to get rid of her. Tries to indicate the threat silently with her eyes, but Solara doesn't get it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She steps into the ditch and starts to haul the cart out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too   late. THREE ROAD BRIGANDS POUNCE FROM THE BUSHES. Every bit   as brutish and horrifying as the group that Eli killed on the   road in our opening. They grab Solara and drag her from the   road into the desert, screaming and kicking all the way.

direction.raw_text: The BRIGAND LEADER looks Solara up and down lustfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Solara is reviled by the man. He's filthy, his stench overpowering. One eye missing, just a dark, empty socket. He licks his lips, revealing a mouth almost devoid of teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The brigand leader lashes out and grabs her by the throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He releases her. She slumps to the dirt, whimpering.

direction.raw_text: He looks back to the struggling Solara.

direction.raw_text: She says nothing, just sobs helplessly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He unbuckles his pants, lets them drop to his ankles. We hear a sound. It's hard to place. Something like a THHUP. The brigand leader is frozen in shock. His face goes pale, the blood draining from it. The two bandits holding Solara look at their leader in dismay. Staring down at his crotch. A quiet whimper escapes from his lips as he looks down. There is an ARROW IMBEDDED IN HIS CROTCH. What was once down there is now just a bloody mess of mangled meat. More blood streams down his thighs. A real horror show. He staggers backward, shrieking. Hands shaking. Staring down at the awful wound from which the long arrow shaft extends. The two other brigands release Solara and whip around, scanning the horizon. They see nothing. result.heading: ELI, WALKING TOWARD THEM FROM THE ROAD, OUT OF THE SUN

direction.raw_text: . His silhouette distorted in the rippling heat. An avenging angel. He pulls another arrow and draws it back as the rifle bandit trains his weapon on him, finger tightening on the trigger. Eli SHOOTS. The arrow sails through the air and RIGHT INTO THE RIFLE BARREL. The feathers at the end of the shaft plugging the muzzle tight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Rifle bandit pulls the trigger. The gun EXPLODES, BLOWING HIS HANDS CLEAN OFF. He falls to the ground, screaming. Eli only had two arrows. He shoulders the bow and draws his sword. All the remaining brigand has is a small knife. The two now square off at arm's length. A hopeless mismatch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The knife brigand hesitates, trembling. And then RUSHES ELI WITH THE KNIFE. Eli deftly sidesteps, flourishes the sword. So quick it almost seems like he didn't move at all. The knife bandit staggers forward a couple more steps. His hand goes limp and drops the knife. And then his HEAD FALLS BACKWARD like a Pez dispenser. Almost completely decapitated, but not quite. Blood fountains from the neck stump as his body falls to the dirt. Eli moves to the other two bandits who lay horribly wounded on the ground, but still breathing. He stands over their fallen bodies. They stare back up at him, helpless. He crouches down between them in the dust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The brigand leader defiantly spits blood at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli sighs. Stands and looks down on him without pity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He plunges his sword into the bandit leader, finishing him off. Pulls the arrow from his crotch and wipes it clean. He turns to the other man, raising his sword.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Eli pauses, sword hovering over him, poised to strike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli crouches once more by his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bandit follows along with Eli, mouthing the words quietly. The life ebbing from him with each moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes roll back as his final breath leaves him. Dead. Eli signs a cross over his body, then stands and walks away. Solara sits on the ground nearby, a wreck. Eli approaches and gathers her up in his arms. She clings on to him tightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She laughs, a tear rolling down her cheek. Grips him tighter. He helps her up and escorts her back to the road.

direction.raw_text: She looks back at the young woman still slumped in the dirt.

direction.raw_text: They walk on down the road.

A DODGE GRAND CARAVAN, similarly customized and armed to the teeth.

The fleet of armored vehicles moves out, kicking up a great funnel of dust in their wake as they roar out of town.

direction.raw_text: Late afternoon. The sun hangs low on the horizon. We're far from the road. Nothing but scrub brush and a few PRAIRIE DOG BURROWS dotted around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pops its head up, scans the horizon. Sniffing the air, whiskers twitching... and is SKEWERED BY AN ARROW. Thirty yards away, one of the pieces of scrub brush appears to COME ALIVE. And then we realize it is Eli's GHILLIE SUIT, camouflaging both he and Solara beneath it. Eli casts off the camouflage net and walks toward the dead prairie dog. Solara just stands there, appalled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli picks up the dead animal by the scruff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He yanks out the bloody arrow. Solara looks away. When she turns back, Eli is standing right there, holding the dead animal in front of her face. She YELPS in surprise and staggers backward, falling on her butt.

dialogue.raw_text: You killed it! That cute little thing!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not funny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're going to be on the road, you can't be picky about what you eat. You eat what's there to eat.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not eating that.

dialogue.raw_text: More for me.

direction.raw_text: Eli and Solara sit in the mouth of a desert cave, around a flickering campfire. The prairie dog roasts on a spit. Eli digs his knife into the carcass, the blade comes out clean. It's done. He clasps his hands together and gazes down penitently at the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli carves off a piece of meat. Juicy and succulent. He bites into it, teasing Solara by making a show of how good it tastes. He feeds a piece to the rat perched on his shoulder. Solara tries to appear uninterested, but she's starved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes another bite, thinks on this as he chews.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She tries to fight the temptation to try it... but she can't. She reaches out and tears off a piece. Sniffs at it, takes a small bite... then quickly wolfs down the rest. Eli smiles. As she eats, she gestures toward Eli's Saint Christopher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli reaches up and touches his hand to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli smiles and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Solara listens, rapt. Eli is a good storyteller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Solara looks at Eli tenderly, with admiration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli looks away, down at the ground. He appears sad.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Father, we thank you for your generosity in providing us with this meal. Bless this food to our use and us to thy service, and keep us ever mindful of the needs of others. Amen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does that taste like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tastes like chicken.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a Saint Christopher medal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's Saint Christopher? Is he a character from your book?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Christopher was a man who lived a long time ago. He wanted to be a good man, he wanted to help people. So he would stand by a river that had no bridge and carry people across. He was a big strong man and there was no one he couldn't carry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then one day a young child came to the river and asked to be carried across. Christopher tried to carry him but he was too heavy. He was just a small boy but he was heavier than any man he had ever carried. The boy explained that he was the son of God, and that he was so heavy because he bore all the sins of the world. After that, Christopher was able to carry him across and when they got to the other side the boy baptized him in the river. And that's how he became a saint. Later on, he was known as the patron saint of travelers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is a saint, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's someone who spent their life doing good things for others. Enough that God himself took a special interest in them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Someone like you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Not like me. Saints ain't killers. And I done too much of that. Spilled too much blood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . No words, just the flickering firelight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT The fire down to its last embers. Eli sleeps next to his pack, half-hidden in the looming shadows of the cave. His hat and goggles hung up for the night on the hilt of his sword. Solara sleeps nearby... then opens her eyes. Not asleep after all. She looks over at Eli - his face hidden in shadow and so impossible to tell if he's asleep or awake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The prison yard shrouded in the dim light just before dawn. Solara crosses the yard. She looks more mature somehow. Determined and strong. She carries with her ELI'S SWORD - and something else, tucked under her arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops in a nondescript corner of the yard. At her feet is a SHALLOW MOUND OF DIRT. At the head of the mound, a SIMPLE TOMBSTONE. She kneels and places a SINGLE FLOWER on the grave.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Thank you for your protection and for your many signs along the way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lit only by the pale moonlight, barely enough to see by. Carnegie sleeps soundly in bed. Next to him lies Claudia, wide awake. She checks that Carnegie is sound asleep, careful not to wake him before she creeps out of bed and exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claudia is on her hands and knees in the darkness, searching blindly in the aisles and beneath the theater seats. She finds Eli's bible in some litter strewn on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sitting in the darkness, Claudia opens the book and runs her fingers across the braille, reading. And though we can barely see in the dim light, we see the smile on her face. The joy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Thank you for the good that I have done. For whatever light you were able to shine into the darkness of this world through me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Solara kneels by the grave, we see now that she wears Eli's SAINT CHRISTOPHER PENDANT around her neck. The tombstone reads:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She unsheathes Eli's sword, plants it in the ground before his grave. Takes the BOOK from under her arm and opens it up. It's a NEW BIBLE. Crudely typeset from Lombardi's original transcription and printed on the prison press. She opens it up and begins to read a passage from the bible over Eli's grave. We don't hear what she says. As Solara finishes her reading and closes the bible, LOMBARDI appears behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stands, pulling Eli's sword from the earth.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: HERE LIES ELIJAH STONE DIED AUGUST 21, 2048 FAITHFUL SERVANT TO THE LORD AND FRIEND TO SOLARA

dialogue.raw_text: You know, you don't have to leave. You're welcome to stay here with us. You'll be safe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I gotta do what I gotta do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where will you go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Solara looks at the sword, her fingers playing across its hilt. The blade glimmers in the light of the rising sun. There is a determined, purposeful look in her eye.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The sun rises through the fog on the horizon. The great iron gates grind open. Solara emerges from inside the prison, steps out onto the island rock. She is dressed in a flak jacket, combat pants and boots. Eli's old pack across her back. Hair tied in a neat pony tail. Atop that, Eli's ragged fur hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . In her hand she clutches a copy of the newly-printed bible. Eli's sword slung over her shoulder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Thank you for the friend I made.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Please watch over her as you watched over me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Solara walks back along Fisherman's Wharf... through the San Francisco rubble... across the Golden Gate bridge...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Thank you for allowing me finally to rest. I'm so very tired. The time of my departure is at hand and now I surrender my soul into your care, at peace in knowing that I have carried out your will. That I have done right with my time on this earth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...and finally back onto a desolate road leading off into the desert wasteland. She looks up and down the road, then turns and heads toward the sun on the horizon. Headed east.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she walks away into the sun, her lonely silhouette on the road reminds us of Eli as we saw him so many times before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She grows smaller and smaller as she walks into the distance, until she consumed by the rising sun and we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I have fought the good fight. I have finished the race.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I have kept the faith.
dialogue.name: dialogue
